title: Friday, 7th September 2018
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:04am

Okay, so we're going slow today because I'm feeling rough.

BE11:04am

(Good morning, hello, hi, etc.)

Manxish Happy Friday internet persons
Soundbuy Morning.Trawling around Mayfair again?
BE11:06am

So .......... Where do we start? Maybe here, I guess.

11:06 am
Plus500 Ltd (PLUS:LSE): Last: 1,490, down 118.37 (-7.36%), High: 1,608, Low: 1,486, Volume: 2.13m
Soundbuy You could just dictate to your intern.......
ghk Why has sterling just jumped?
GBKrona Hola
DRichi Good morning
BE11:07am

So what's happened is that its founders including one current director decided midway through yesterday to press the button on selling 8 per cent, or half their stakes.

Grouchmonkey Morning all, back from hols and cheered by the results from Greene King!
OnYourRight Morning all. I hope everyone enjoyed the summer hols?
BE11:07am

Then, next morning, Playtech dumps its entire 9.9 per cent.

Blank canvas morning all
OnYourRight @BE Too many Pimms?
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Unconnected events, of coure. Not suggesting otherwise. To be clear.

BE11:09am

The timing is intersting though, you have to say, given the New ESMA regulations on CFD dealers.

chopper bear can anyone stop the rot and bayer please :-(
Badger The timing on ESMA though had been known for some time
BE11:09am

And Playtech isn't an entirely disinterested party here either, since it owns Tradetech: https://www.tradetech-group.com/

11:10 am
BE11:10am

If directors are selling ahead of ESMA, and founders are selling ahead of ESMA, and industry insiders are selling ahead of ESMA, who's buying?

Badger Excellent question. And that volume too.
BE11:12am

We need to remember that activists are .... Or, at least, they're buying Playtech.

Playtech PLC (PTEC:LSE): Last: 485.80, down 1.2 (-0.25%), High: 515.00, Low: 482.80, Volume: 1.08m
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Odey (who for shorthand we'll call an activist) confirms going up to 5% yesterday I think, which matches Springowl.

Hamster on a Piano anything on FGP or RGB rumours?
BE11:14am

You can see the Plus500 sale in that context, though I doubt balance sheet underpinning's that important to those two versus the potential of a trade sale or a hiving off of the Asian business.

BE11:14am

Still, mildly positive if you want to view Playtech as an actual company rather than a special sit. Here's Citi.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

We estimate that the Plus 500 sale effectively reduces headline net debt in FY19e from €593 million to €421 million, after incorporating the gross sale proceeds and lower dividend income. We estimate that FY19e net debt to EBITDA will reduce from 1.4x to 1.0x.

BE11:15am

We have a Buy rating on Playtech. At an 8.3x FY19e PE ratio, the shares are showing significant value at current levels. We see potential for positive catalysts to emerge over the next 12 months from contract negotiations with News UK that may improve the structure of the Sun Bingo agreement, potential entry into the US sports betting market and an Italy focused CMD scheduled for November 2018.

BE11:16am

And Goodbody.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

This mornings announcement will come as no surprise. To recap, ahead of its upcoming refinancing of c.€1bn of debt to fund the Snaitech deal, Playtech had adjusted gross cash of €563m on the balance sheet at the end of H118, of which c.€350m is potentially available to reduce the quantum of debt needed and it had been suggested that the Plus500 stake could be sold to further reduce the level of debt required. Final details of the Snai refinancing are expected in the coming months.

undefined
BE11:17am

(Hamster: what the hell's RGB?)

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And so, to buses.

FirstGroup PLC (FGP:LSE): Last: 94.70, down 1.25 (-1.30%), High: 103.30, Low: 93.75, Volume: 1.67m
Alchemy30 Morning, Think he means RBG
Flaneur Whats exposed to Swedens election this weekend?
BE11:18am

Bloomberg saying CVC's interested, among others, which ...... yeah, probably.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

https://www.bloomb...rest-including-cvc

BE11:19am

FirstGroup Plc, the operator of Greyhound buses and British trains, is attracting interest from buyout firms including CVC Capital Partners as it conducts a review of the business, people familiar with the matter said.

The buyout firm has not made a formal bid and deliberations are in early stages, the people said, asking not to be identified as the details aren’t public. FirstGroup, which has a market value of 1.2 billion pounds ($1.5 billion), this year rejected proposals from Apollo Global Management LLC, saying in May that they “fundamentally undervalued” the business. Potential bidders may make offers for part or all of the business, the people said.

Hamster on a Piano RBG yes oops
BE11:21am

Market response is probably fair enough. "PE looking at company that PE firm has already looked at, and that's in a strategy review likely involving possible division sales", feels a bit incremental.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Here's RBC.

Soundbuy First Group - you wait ages for 1 market comment then 3 ............zzzzzz
BE11:22am

Sorry, no, have Liberum instead.

BE11:23am

Such interest seems inevitable in the wake of prior interest from Apollo private equity funds and hints of a more rigorous review of the business by management. It remains to be seen whether this translates into anything formal, either for parts of the business or for the group as a whole. We see an opportunity to bridge the gap between FirstGroup’s market-leading positions and its sub-par financial performance. Obstacles remain, notably the pension deficit and UK rail franchises, but none are insurmountable.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Bit more on the obstacles here.

BE11:23am

he pension deficit and UK Rail business remain key obstacles to either a full takeover or material disposals. Small disposals may need to factor in potential value leakage through the need to make an additional one-off deficit reduction contribution. Larger disposals could necessitate extensive negotiation with the pension trustees, with a significant cash injection likely to be required to mitigate the increased risk faced by the scheme if it were to be supported by a smaller and less well diversified sponsoring company.

Rail franchise contracts require government approval for change of control. We see it as highly unlikely private equity will be allowed to own rail franchises, doubly so in the current political environment, so suitably qualified trade buyers would need to be lined up at the outset. Assuming it is possible for these obstacles to be overcome, we suspect it will be difficult for management to turn away interest for a second time while the group’s performance has remained relatively lacklustre.

BE11:23am

And the distressed valuation.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

FirstGroup trades on a March 2019E P/E of 7.3x and EV/EBITDA of 3.7x (ex-rail cash). These represent a substantial discount to the peer group average (30% in calendarised 2019E P/E terms, 38% in EV/EBITDA terms). As ever, we believe traditional multiples are not the best valuation method due to the distortion from finite and high risk rail earnings. The depressed rating is unsurprising given the group’s disappointing performance in recent years. However, this has not been without some success (e.g. First Student turnaround) and we continue to see opportunity in bridging the gap between strong market positions and below par financial performance, one way or another.

BE11:24am

Remember the seven or eight thousand stories that were written about PE circling Costa?

BE11:24am

And then the Coke bid appeared entirely from leftfield and settled the issue?

11:25 am
BE11:25am

If you're looking to chase bid rumours, "PE mulling stuff" isn't the most secure of starting points.

Shinshin Anyone calculating impact of 4% GDPR fine on BA outlook ?
undefined
BE11:27am

Revolution Bars is Ben: https://www.betavi...lution-bars-group/

11:27 am
Revolution Bars Group PLC (RBG:LSE): Last: 117.45, up 2.95 (+2.58%), High: 117.45, Low: 116.80, Volume: 219.40k
BE11:28am

No statement yet, but you'd assume one would be required if he's right.

BE11:28am

And, let's face it, he's probably right.

11:28 am
undefined
Pharma @Shinshin, 4% is a maximum fine, no? No chance of that happening first time.
BE11:30am

Elsewhere .............. International Consolidated British Aeroplanes Dirigibles Suchlike Group PLC ......

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 660.00, down 21.2 (-3.11%), High: 669.40, Low: 642.00, Volume: 3.30m
11:30 am
BE11:30am

380,000 customers have their deets nicked.

BE11:31am

Including, potentially, credit cards.

BE11:32am

IAG says it's a sophisticated hack, which is nice. Good to hear they weren't hacked by bozos who didn't know what they were doing. Also says site encryption wasn't compromised, suggesting it's some kind of middleman sniping thing.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Cost will be insured, they say.

BE11:33am

Here's RBC, which worries more about reputation than cost.

BE11:33am

Reputation at risk (again): This has echoes of Talk Talk, TSB and other breaches, and will likely carry reputation/trust risk. At TSB, IT failures eventually cost the CEO his job. At IAG, we think this would add to the risk - as changing CEO part way through a major change itself carries risks.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Though not related, coming on top of other (operational) IT failures this is not helpful. How IAG's BA now assists affected customers will therefore be key. If it proves hard to contact likely overwhelmed BA customer contact lines and card issuers, this may compound the problem. Thus far, the company's 'customer contact' has appeared to be a very general email suggesting customers contact their card issuers.

BE11:34am

Seems to me a reasonable difference between flying BA and signing up to TalkTalk. If I want an internet provider I have dozens of choices at the budget end of the market, whereas if I want a flight to Boston I'll tend to go with whoever's available for the time I want.

BE11:35am

The fact that there were awkward headlines a few weeks back about dodgy IT probably won't affect my decision much.

jaws BE you got anything SAGE please.
11:36 am
undefined
Pharma Comparison with TSB is silly. At TSB the CEO signed off on a doomed IT-switch over, without a proper fall-back plan. He then went on the record saying everything was fine, when clearly it wasn't.
BE11:36am

(@jaws: Nope. Apropos of what?)

BE11:37am

Turning to results, there's Greene King.

11:37 am
Greene King PLC (GNK:LSE): Last: 514.80, up 39.8 (+8.38%), High: 539.60, Low: 489.80, Volume: 1.60m
jaws BE ticker SGE please. i think last week lot talik when we were off here. Thank you.
sprout ING in the doghouse today re IT also.
BE11:39am

Big rally on a decent trading update. Doesn't really settle the concerns about too much debt, but there's a bit more hope that sales might be able to keep pace with cost inflation.

BE11:39am

Shore Cap can summarise.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

LFL sales in the core managed pub division (Pub Company) were ahead by 2.8% in the first 18 weeks of the financial year, including +3.2% in the last 10 weeks. Unsurprisingly, the performance was driven primarily by wet-led pubs given the favourable weather over the summer and the World Cup with its branded locals ahead by 5.5% in the period; although we understand
that the group has traded ahead of the industry (CGA Peach Coffer) across all segments suggesting that the investment in the offering last year continues to deliver momentum. Elsewhere, pub partners (tenanted) was down 0.3% over 16 weeks, although we understand LFL net income adjusted for the timing of costs was ahead by over 2%, and total beer volumes were ahead by 4.0%.

BE11:40am

The statement also highlights that gross cost inflation of £45-50m is unchanged with cost mitigation of c£30-35m on track, with the group on course to dispose of c100-110 pubs (£60-70m proceeds). With over a third of the year gone Greene King it is encouraging to see that Greene King is tracking ahead of full year consensus estimates for Pub Company LFL sales growth of c+0.5-1.0%. Our 2019F PBT estimate for flat PBT of £243m (EPS: 62.7p) is predicated on 1% LFL sales growth. To meet this requires broadly flat LFL sales growth for the remainder of the financial year with the group also facing easier comps over the winter, following last year’s heavy snow. At this stage we leave our full year estimates unchanged. Greene Kin trades on a 2019F PER of 8.4x, an EV/EBITDA of 7.4x and a dividend of 6.3%.
We see such metrics as too low given the asset backing and the additional financial flexibility when the group completes the refinancing of the Spirit securitisaiton. BUY.

Grouchmonkey Seems to me that "the data disaster" is a rite of passage for most companies, these days.
BE11:42am

The counterpoint here, which we've written several times, is that summer was perfect for pub operators. It can be considered exceptional and tells you little about the underlying trends.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Shares ahve come back a lot already on that kind of thinking, though. Here's Peel Hunt.

rw42 Was a mail in Reg comments about IAG outsourcing IT security to IBM at the start of August, unfortunate timing!
BE11:43am

The EV/EBITDA valuation is below the 2008-09 financial crisis/recession
level. In comparison, if managed LFL sales can exceed 1.5% in 2019E, the
combination of profit and dividend growth, as well as net debt reduction,
should return. Given this and a dividend yield of 7%, we are upgrading our
recommendation to Buy.

BE11:43am

Numis says the opposite.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

We do not expect consensus to change this early in the year;the company guided to flat PBT at the FY18 results and has not changed this. Our estimates were based on 1% growth in managed lfl sales and 2% growth in tenanted net income. We now assume managed lfls +1.5% (1% for the remainder of the year) and flat lfls in tenanted. This leaves our forecasts broadly unchanged in overall terms.

BE11:44am

GNK trades on an undemanding 2019 P/E of 8.7x (10.3x provision
adjusted) and EV/EBITDA of 8.1x with a 6.3% dividend yield. Given recent share price weakness (-22% over 1Q) and low rating, the shares have short-term recovery potential. However, there is a risk that if growth normalises post World Cup, lfl sales will still be insufficient this year to offset the £10-15m expected net cost inflation. As a result, we maintain our cautious stance – similar to all the managed pub majors (GNK, MAB, JDW).

undefined
Electric Dragon @Shinshin also GDPR fines are dependent on communicating promptly to affected customers - the quicker you do it, the more lenient the ICO will be. To prevent an Equifax type situation where they sat on knowledge of the breach for ages.
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Ooh!

BE11:45am

https://www.ft.com...-99ca-68cf89602132

BE11:45am

UK bookstore Waterstones announced on Friday it would acquire rival Foyles for an undisclosed sum, as part of its fight back against online giant Amazon’s “siren call.”

11:45 am
BE11:46am

The deal is expected to complete before the end of the year, although the terms have not been disclosed.

Waterstones, which has 283 bookshops across the UK, Ireland, the Netherlands and Belgium, is owned by American billionaire Paul Singer’s Elliott Management Company. Meanwhile, the formerly family-owned Foyles has four stores in London and shops in Bristol, Birmingham and Chelmsford.

BE11:46am

Foyles' brand probably needs rescuing at this point.

Excel Developer book store monopoly
Grouchmonkey Bit odd to call Foyles a "rival" to waterstones - it's tiny by comparison?
Flaneur @ExDev - anything that keeps highstreet bookstores alive is okay with me...
BE11:50am

The expansion went wrong and they've been in an unorganised retreat ever since. As best demonstrated by the shutdown of part of the flagship shop on Charing Cross Road .....

bennyj901 Seems like a futile move in my opinion. Went to my local Waterstones last week and the place was completely empty.
Pharma I wonder if 283 bookstores + 7 will equal 284.
11:50 am

.... which resulted in a sushi place moving in and stealing two-thirds of their sign.

chopper bear centamin gold ? anything floating around
Excel Developer @flaneur: I even might write one, now that I know it is possible to put clickable adverts in a pdf.
11:53 am
BE11:53am

(Bulletin boards on Sirius are extraordinary, if you can spare a moment or two for a look. Hundreds of posts ever hour, many of which are sounding off about how AIM's crooked.)

BE11:54am

(Sirius is, of course, SETS traded.)

BE11:54am

Nothing much to add, really, apart from JPM's comment on yesterday's costs warning.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

We expect the market’s first take will likely focus on the capex increase, which may perpetuate cynicism
around near-term funding and longer-term construction development scheduling risk, particularly in the context of
Sirius’ market cap size and POLY4 market risk. Furthermore, the funding “gap” may also heighten concerns around
equity dilution for current and / or potential new investors, although we note this continues to remain management’s least preferred option. Taking a “glass half full” approach, today’s announcement replaces stale capex estimates (last updated in 2016) which provides greater clarity around capital requirements for the business. Practical completion of procurement, coupled with offtake rhetoric (which strongly indicates contracted tonnes above the prior target), should ultimately give greater confidence around the likelihood of Stage 2 funding given these two factors are firmly on the immediate critical path. On valuation, using SXX’s “contract price” EBITDA scenario of $1.4bn (at 13Mtpa), we calculate implies ~4.5x EV/EBITDA multiple at full production which represents a steep discount to fertilizer comps which typically trade at ~9-12x forward. We remain Overweight with (unch) £0.45/sh Dec’18 PT.

BE11:55am

They are, as we pointed out yesterday, house broker.
